Award.AwardTitle: Photoinitiated Reactions in Covalent Adaptable Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Bowman, Christopher
Institution: University of Colorado
Proposal Number: 1264298
Title:Photoinitiated Reactions in Covalent Adaptable Networks

Crosslinked polymer networks, also often referred to as thermosets, represent one of the most ubiquitous polymer systems, being used in composites, biomedical devices, dental materials, coatings, adhesives, optical components, and photolithography. While these covalently crosslinked structures impart a number of highly desirable features, particularly with respect to the mechanics, they largely limit the subsequent shape and performance of the polymer system to those that are achieved at the end of the polymerization. Here, the PI plans to work with a distinct class of thermosetting systems that combine the necessary covalently crosslinked structure with internal functional groups that undergo addition-fragmentation reactions upon exposure to light that enable the network to rearrange. This reactive ability to break and reform bonds in a controlled manner enables these materials to demonstrate a number of unique properties not commonly found in other thermosets, such as stress relaxation, reduced polymerization induced stress, the ability to photolithographically define shape and topography, to act as multistage shape memory polymers (SMPs) and to have the ability to alleviate stress locally as a means for preventing catastrophic material failure. Ultimately, upon application of the necessary stimulus, these materials "adapt" or respond to their conditions and have been referred to as Covalent Adaptable Networks (CANs). The PI plans to utilize light as one of the most potent and capable triggers for this reactive process as light enables 4D (temporal plus 3D spatial) control of the reactions that facilitate the network property and behavioral changes.

This work is to advance the development of CANs, as controllable by photoinduced radical generation. The overall objective is to create novel, functional CAN-based materials that are more readily formed, enable complete and repeatable adaptation, and facilitate the achievement of new properties including the formation of arbitrary topographical and refractive index features, photothermal SMPs, and stress-triggered network relaxation. The research program is divided into four principal scientific directions: (i) development of new monomers, polymers and understanding of structure-property relationships in CANs based on systematic molecular structural variations, (ii) the implementation of those CANs in reactions that enable 4D lithographic control of topography, shape and refractive index, (iii) the development of combined adaptable/non-adaptable networks to achieve multistage SMP behavior, and (iv) use of mechanochemical species that cleave into radicals upon application of stress to induce stress relaxation and prevent catastrophic material failure in a "smart" manner. Each scientific direction is coupled to education and training of a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students. Attainment will facilitate understanding of polymer network dynamics as well as development of materials that have significant advantages over conventional thermosets.

Potential breakthroughs will be achieved by enabling dramatic changes in material shape and properties by exposure to light, by facilitating photothermal SMPs and by developing techniques through which thermosetting polymers could have extended service lifetimes. For example, the ability to form multiheight features photolithographically (without solvents and without contact to the exposed area) simply by changing the grayscale level represents a disruptive resist technology where a single exposure during a mechanical deformation will be used to create a complex array of heights just by changing the intensity at each location. Similarly, forming smart thermosetting materials that have the capacity to autonomously alleviate stress could lead to significantly enhanced service lifetimes of these materials, particularly in composite materials and when used with other approaches to healable networks.

Successful completion of this work should have significant intellectual merit through understanding of how reaction dynamics associated with bond breakage and reformation dictate the network structure, in enhancing formation-structure-property relationships in CANs and other thermosets, and in the creation of new monomers and classes of materials that combine the benefits of thermosets with the ability to trigger desired property and shape changes with light. This approach will simultaneously have significant broader impacts associated with the launching of a new PhD degree program and the training of diverse personnel in a unique combination of chemical reactions and polymer networks while also enabling a critical missing element of spatiotemporal control in this new, powerful material's paradigm. Implementation of these newly controlled and more simply implemented reactions and materials will benefit an array of polymer applications including SMPs, adhesives, photolithographic resists, optical elements, composites, coatings, and biomedical materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymers are generally categorized as either thermoplastics or thermosets.  Thermoplastics, i.e, “plastics”, denote polymeric materials that flow at elevated temperatures.  These polymers are linear macromolecules while thermosets are polymers whose chains are reacted together by covalent bonds and are thus more resistant to heat and solvent.  Each material has its own unique advantages and disadvantages making them appropriate for different applications.  Thermoplastics are easily reprocessed into a variety of shapes to suit the desired application.  A polyethylene milk carton  may be melted and recycled as part of a park bench.  Thermoplastics are, however, often soft and susceptible to rapid loss of mechanical integrity in the presence of solvent or heat.  Thermosets are harder, tougher materials used as coatings, adhesives or in structural applications, but their form is fixed at the point of production.  For example, a vulcanized rubber tire can never be melted and reshaped, preventing many potential recycling applications. 

Covalent Adaptable Networks (CANs), as developed here, bridge the divide between thermoplastics and thermosets, combining mechanical properties of the latter with reprocessability of the former with on-demand activation of the transition between the two.  One example of a CAN uses Diels Alder chemistry to form the network.  Subjected to adequate heat, these bonds rearrange, allowing the material to be remolded or reformed.  The stimulus that facilitates the rearrangement of chemical bonds in CANs was often heat.  In this way, these CANs closely resemble thermoplastics.  There are other stimuli, however, capable of triggering molecular rearrangement within CANs that lead to advantageous qualities.  Here, light was used as a low energy alternative to heat.  But in addition to great potential energy savings, light offers some additional capabilities that heat does not.  Photoinitiated reactions are confined to where and when a material is exposed to light, giving this approach unparalleled spatial and temporal control over the plasticity of the material.

This project, “Photoinitiated Reactions in Covalent Adaptable Networks” developed and expanded the technology of employing various wavelengths of light to enable and control light-induced plasticity in CANs.  Photoplasticity was achieved via a radical rearrangement of allyl sulfides and trithiocarbonates, which is readily compatible with polymerization chemistry.  In this way chemical bonds are broken and reformed simultaneously.  Because this process is radically mediated, it was achieved with the employment of compounds that decompose into radical species upon exposure to various wavelengths of light (i.e., photoinitiators). 

The ability to control, via light, the rearrangement of covalent bonds was explored in a variety of phases pertinent to thermosets.  In addition to the development of new materials with advantageous mechanical properties by the employment of various crosslinking reactions, schemes were devised for the employment of different wavelengths of light to elicit different responses.  For example, the material may be crosslinked with a blue light and the plasticity induced with a UV light. 

Thermosets are most often encountered as composite materials, where filler is included in the formulation to impart desirable properties to the material.  As one example, dental fillings polymerized in one’s mouth, for example, are typically a crosslinked polymer with a high percentage of glass filler that hardens the material against wear.  The interactions at the filler-resin interface contribute disproportionately to the mechanical properties of the material.  In this research inclusion of photoinduceable rearrangement of bonds at this surface led to greatly improved toughness of composites. 

The combination of photoinduced plasticity with thermally responsive liquid crystalline elastomers (LCEs) enabled dual handles on the shape changing attributes of crosslinked materials, finally allowing one to fit the proverbial square peg into a round hole (Figure 1) repeatedly and reversibly. 

This outcome was accomplished by polymerizing a round peg, at high temperature where the LCE monomers would be disordered.  At a low temperature, the LC groups that would organize into an ordered phase were prevented by the crosslinks.  But, when pressed into a square shape and exposed to the appropriate wavelength of light to enable the bond exchange, the LC groups were permitted to form that ordered phase.  Heating caused the reversion to the round peg, but cooling would return the shape to its square state.  Similar procedures were capable of creating materials with much more complicated shape transitions such as the origami crane in Figure 2. 

This project demonstrated the unprecedented control over the shape and mechanical properties of materials by exposure to defined wavelengths of light, portending not only improvements in the processability of crosslinked materials, but materials with altogether new and exciting capabilities.

Results have already been disseminated through 8 publications, e.g., in Science Advances, Macromolecules, Polymer, Soft Matter, Advanced Materials and Polymer Chemistry cited more than 135 times already (Web of Science) with presentations at numerous invited and contributed talks. This project impacted 6 Ph.D. graduate students and 3 undergraduate students, and the PI launched a new PhD degree in Materials Science and Engineering.
